title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We passed a pretty shooting place of Sir W. Stewart's, called Rohallion, nearly at the foot of Birnam.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: Flora's face, the memory of past years of love and kindness experienced from Lady Winifred, and from the old Lord, melted his heart, or filled it with regard and gratitude towards them, and he felt that, go where he might, Rohallion  could never be forgotten.

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: viscount, earl, or lord, but were simply styled as the Masters of Marischal, Glencairn, Glam- mis, Lindesay, Rohallion, and so forth, a custom existing in Scotland to the present day, in most houses, under ducal rank.

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: But Rohallion survived his disappointment, and the two following years glided peacefully away, at his old castle in Carrick.

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: But whether they were ugly toys, or actors in some scene the child had witnessed, Rohallion could not tell; he supposed  the affair referred to was some grim reality incident to 'the late revolution.

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: Kind old Rohallion was deeply interested in and attracted by the little boy, who had many winning and endearing ways about him \ and lie particularly  excelled in a bright and captivating smile, that was joyous in its perfect innocence.

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: " ' Josephine,' " said he, reading the inscription  upon the riug ; " why, that is the name of the widow Beauharnais, who three or four years ago married the First Consul to escape the guillotine  ! You must preserve these relics with care, Winny ; and as for the poor bairn, Rohallion must be his home till we find his mother, a task very unlikely to be accomplished, if ever at all, in these times, when France is at war with all the world, and her scaffolds are drenched daily with the blood of women, children, and priests, as well as of brave and loyal gentlemen.

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: "By the handwriting, Rohallion, and by the crest on the ring "

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: n Cosmo will be twenty-five on his next birth-day," said Lady Rohallion, thoughtfully, a remark probably suggested by the term " boy ;" " our only son, Rohallion ; we must indeed be careful of him."

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: Then, Andrews, as if according to use and wont, without requiring to be told, removed the decanters, and placed before his master the " three elements," whisky, hot water, and sugar, and Rohallion, with ladle and jug, proceeded to make a jorum of hot steaming toddy.

title: The King's own borderers :
author: Grant, James
snippet: "And now, Rohallion, tell me about our Cosmo — how is he looking?"
